title: 107_s2635
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission Act of 2002". In 1609, Englishman Henry Hudson and French explorer Samuel de Champlain made significant voyages, leading to early European exploration and discovery of America. The early contacts between Native Americans and Europeans in the New World led to the establishment of Dutch and English settlements in Albany, New York, and French Quebec settlements as far south as Lake George. These early settlements influenced the history, culture, law, commerce, and traditions of the United States. In 1807, Robert Fulton's steamboat Clermont successfully inaugurated steam navigation on a commercial basis, marking a significant event in history. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission was established to observe the significant historical events related to navigation, commerce, naval warfare, and international relations in the United States. The National Park Service in New York owns resources related to early US history and the Hudson River Valley, and in 2002, the State of New York created a commission for this purpose. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission was established to ensure a suitable national observance in 2009 of the anniversaries of Henry Hudson, Robert Fulton, and Samuel de Champlain's voyages. The commission aims to assist in providing an excellent visitor experience, promoting interaction with natural and cultural resources, and recognizing the diverse communities along the Hudson River and Lake Champlain. Additionally, it seeks to facilitate international involvement in the observances. The Fulton-Champlain 2009 observances aim to support marketing efforts for commemorative items and assist in developing heritage tourism and economic benefits for the United States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Commemoration" refers to honoring specific historical voyages, "Commission" refers to the established Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission, "Governor" refers to the Governor of each State, "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" specifically includes the State of New York. The term "State" in this Act includes the State of New York, New Jersey, and Vermont, along with their agencies and entities. SEC. 4. HUDSON-FULTON-CHAMPLAIN COMMEMORATION COMMISSION. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission is established with 31 members appointed by the Secretary, Governors, and Members of the House of Representatives representing Hudson River Valley and Champlain Valley. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission has 6 members appointed by the Secretary, including 2 employees of the National Park Service, 1 individual knowledgeable about the Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area, and 5 individuals with relevant expertise. The Hudson-Fulton-Champlain Commemoration Commission consists of 6 members appointed by the Secretary, including individuals with expertise related to the commemoration. Members serve for the life of the Commission and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission meets at least twice a year or as called by the Chairperson or majority of members. The initial meeting must be held within 30 days of all members being appointed. Decisions require an affirmative vote by a majority of members, with a quorum being a majority of the Commission. The Commission appoints a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson annually. The Commission appoints a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson annually from among its members. The Vice Chairperson serves as the Chairperson in their absence. The Commission's duties include planning, developing, and executing commemorative programs, coordinating activities with state commissions and federal agencies. The Commission appoints a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson annually from among its members to plan and execute commemorative programs. Federal agencies and organizations are encouraged to participate in expanding activities. The Commission appoints a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson annually to plan and execute commemorative programs. They provide technical assistance, coordinate research, and ensure a lasting legacy for the Hudson-Fulton-Champlain 2009 anniversaries. The Commission prepares a strategic plan and final report, including activities summary, financial accounting, and recommendations. The Commission has powers to carry out its activities. The Commission has the power to accept donations, appoint advisory committees, authorize actions, procure supplies, and use the United States mails. The Commission can use the United States mails, make grants to communities and organizations, and fund research on voyages. Commission members serve without compensation, except for federal employees. The Commission members, who are federal employees, serve without additional compensation. They are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. The Chairperson can appoint and terminate staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and the Chairperson can set their compensation without adhering to standard federal pay regulations. The executive director and personnel of the Commission have a maximum pay rate set at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail their personnel to assist the Commission in its duties under this Act. The Commission can accept personnel from States and reimburse them. They can also use voluntary and uncompensated services. The National Park Service will provide support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may procure temporary services as needed. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. The Commission's authority does not supersede that of the States or the National Park Service. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 2010.
